comments.commentBody:
"Most competitive league in any sport in all the world"....

Why do people say that about EPL? This story is so great, so compelling precisely because the opposite is true. In the worlds most competitive league, you would not be able to play rock-paper-scissors and choose Chelsea, Man-U or Man-City and be right 90% of the time. I can't think of a less competitive league, frankly... Maybe Spanish Premira.

No, you need to look no farther than the bookies to tell this story: 5000-1.

Brian, it is, by far, the richest league in the world, and it distributes revenues more equitably than any other European League does. Even relegation bait, which Leicester was last year, sign big name internationals. Last year, Leicester's best player was former Inter treble winner and Argentine international Estebian Cambiasso. Why 5000-1 to win the league? Cambiasso left. Incredibly, Leicester signed Swiss International Gokhan Inler away from Napoli, where he'd seen regular CL action, to replace Cambiasso, but with the instant emergence of Kante, he hardly played at all, and might be the closest to a bust of the players Ranieri brought in.
The media rights are so yuge going forward that there will be more talent on all sides up and down the division.

One of the most special seasons in sports history as Leicester aims to finish its run at the top of the Premier League. Even a life-time Arsenal fan cannot wait to see this extraordinary team winning the most competitive league in any sport in all the world. It's like a junior high basketball team playing an entire season in the NBA and winning the championship title at the end. You could not make this up.

This timeline doesn't even include the fact that they were only promoted to the Premier League in the 2013-14 season.   My team, the Queens Park Rangers also were promoted; but sadly couldn't hang on and were relegated again.

Hopefully a loss to ManU (who wouldn't want Rashford, Martial and Fosu-Mensah in next year's Champions League? - and there's always the excuse of Vardy being out) and then two thumping wins against Everton and Chelsea.  Maybe not Ranieri's "Hollywood ending," but a pretty darn good one, and one which gives a better shot to the three amazing youngsters at ManU of playing in Europe next year.  But any way they do it, hoping Leicester wins the league.  They are playing full throttle all-in soccer from start to finish, on both offense and defense.  They deserve to win.  Feel sorry for Tottenham, realizing they've never won the BPL either, but they are an incredibly powerful team and should remain a force for years to come.

success is when preparation meets opportunity. this is the case of
Leicester city. one always needs luck sometimes. However, you also need the will to win too.

Right on, Paul. Am a Spurs supporter, but am appreciating Leicester City's accomplishment. You're right to mention Fuchs and Okazaki - their heroism has been relatively unsung.   The players of Leicester City are not the most famous or best paid, but they play as a team, and as a result, they beat the teams of high-priced so-called stars. It makes a person's heart glad.

True, yukon. But it is impossible to envision this result had there been injuries to Kante, Vardy, Mahrez, Morgan or Huth. They were the healthiest team in the league, and they used the fewest players. But every weekend, the NBCSN studio crew kept wondering when the team was goung to crack under the pressure, but one by one, in order, Man City, Arsenal and now Spurs have all cracked. Leicester hasn't, and it's fascinating to see.

It was great circumstance to allow Leicester to do this. They went on a run under Nigel Pearson to actually escape relegation going away. But Ranieri is an undoubted upgrade. Remarkably, Ranieri has never won a league championship, but has finished second...a lot. His Roma side in 2010 lost a lead late to allow Mourinho's Inter the chance for its treble. He finshed second with Chel$ki, which impelled the Ru$$ian Oligarch to replace him with Mourinho, fresh off winning the European Cup with Porto.
Ranieri made three impact buys. He plucked N'Golo Kante from obscurity in France to be short listed for the EPL player of the year. He got Christian Fuchs on a free. And those clean sheets started about when Fuchs forced his way into the every match XI. Experienced, he scored the last goal last year at the Bernabeu when Schalke almost pulled off an impossible comeback against Real. He's their left footed outside dead ball and corner man. And he bought Shinji Okazaki, a starter at Mainz. Not a bust in the group. Okazaki helped pick up when Vardy cooled down to human performance.
But Leicester also had a complete absence of impact injuries, and nobody lost form enough to adversely impact performance, either.
It's a remarkable performance, a remarkable collective overachievement. And in Ranieri, this couldn't happen to a classier gaffer.
free speech for my side not for your side

This is a ridiculous comment.  I'm the last person in the world to vote for Trump, but your logic can be applied to anyone by anyone who disagrees.  The right to speak goes both ways or it's pretty worthless.  How hard is that to believe in?

I applaud those who protested peacefully. Those who destroyed property, assaulted or threatened others and endangered the general public deserve condemnation. Just as we condemn the on the right that act the same.

You can't have it both ways, Robin.

I am proud of the people who showed up to protest Donald Trump’s presence this morning in the Bay Area and I reject the criticism that these (mostly young) people are trying to deny Trump his right to free speech.
Since last June, Trump has been granted an abundance of (literally) free speech, thanks to ratings-driven mainstream news outlets. CNN, Fox and MSNBC have covered his every utterance...thereby subsidizing his campaign.
So how else, but by causing a disturbance and disrupting the flow of traffic, can voices of not-wealthy people EVER be heard? If demonstrations are peaceful...then, to news outlets, they’re boring...and will be ignored.

You mean as opposed to the modern right: violent, intolerant and wrapping themselves in the American Flag? Yeah, both sides have healing to do and sweetping generalizations are pretty much worthless unless you are a Trump supporter where sweeping generalizations become TRUTH.

Trump is no more the face of the modern right (thank goodness) than thse protestors are the face of the modern right.
Belief in the cleansing power of fire will leave this whole country in ashes, with no phoenix in sight.

In the 2000 primaries, George W Bush received more than 12 million votes - 62% of the total - making him a clear winner over John McCain. Trump currently has about 10 million votes - less than 40% of those cast. If the Republican vote were not spread among so many candidates, by this time Trump would be in pretty much the same place as John McCain was in 2000.

This is a quick look at one primary contest. There may be a record number of voters, but Trumps totals do not tell a story of dominance. By the way, Bernie Sanders has received about the same number of votes as Trump, and Hillary Clinton has gained more than 13 million votes.
except that he lives is a nation of millions.  That whole dictotor thing never works out for anyone.  Seriously.

For the longest time I thought it would be prudent for Mr. Trump to tone down his rhetoric and reel in his personal insults. However, as this race has evolved it has become abundantly clear that no matter what he does or says the leaders within his own Party are never going to embrace him. In fact, even as he rolls up victory after victory and compiles the most votes ever accumulated by a Republican candidate, the Party elite plot his demise at every turn.
Consequently, with apparently no support in sight and with nothing to lose, Trump continues to lash out much to the delight of millions of totally fed up followers from all spectrums of the voting bloc.......and the delegate count grows & grows.
As a native New Yorker he has determined that he is going to do it: One Way.....His Way....All the Way......

Ever consider if "liberals", conservatives, moderates, and everyone in between - i.e. US CITIZENS and their elected officials - all worked together, we could do better than we're doing now?  We've become a tribal society where too many are in it for themselves and no one wants to cooperate to build a better nation... we're becoming like Iraq.  The provision of Checks and Balances has been lost ever since Republicans in Congress decided they were going to do nothing... it's hard to mess up or offend anyone if you don't do anything - unfortunately during that time nothing is accomplished.
Why not just rely on the voters?

Trump acted like an adult for a bit after the NY win, but said a few days later... "You know, being presidential's easy - much easier than what I have to do," he told thousands at a rally in Bridgeport, Connecticut. "Here, I have to rant and rave. I have to keep you people going. Otherwise you're going to fall asleep on me, right?"
The pigeons must be fed so the show goes on..
And think of all the money we will save by closing down those Texas military bases and selling off the property to local Xenophobes!
Oh, Daniel - if only!!

@sharon

I wish I had time to answer this better, but we are off to see the Met broadcast of Electra. We are three hours behind you here.

As we have seen from the studies Trump supporters have abut the lowest educational level, and income level among the GOP voters. Their understanding of the government comes from sources such as Fox News, Rush, and other right wing sources that sound plausible. Conspiracy ideas are part of their lives, helping to explain why they have not got ahead like many of their neighbors.

They have lost their jobs to companies that sent their sources to other countries and believe those countries are "stealing" those jobs. The do not have the technical know how to compete at a higher level. This is not true of all of them of course, and there are those who profit by keeping these people in the fold.

They are also believers in the America the great, ignoring the fat, that citizens of other countries believe their own country to be great. America first means more than just it is my home and I love it. I means America has to dominate everyone else. For awhile we did, but we also exported our ideas elsewhere and they are catching up. They have been told the politicians have sold them out, and it makes sense to them.

I could go one here the more I think about it, but have an opera to go see. Thanks for asking.

Ted Cruz's Dad: "My Son Ran for President After God Sent His Wife a Sign."
According to Boehner Cruz was sent by Lucifer.

In all my years I have never seen or heard such an arrogant, self important fatherless offspring of a female canine as Cruz. The GOP fascination with sexual proclivities must have some sort of mental aberration driving it. It seems to have the same psychological underpinnings attributed to most perverts.

Fundamentalist Christianity is another mental disturbance, I can just imagine Cruz making an executive order banning theories of modern geology, evolution, paleontology, cosmology, or other modern discoveries relating to science.

This is the laughing stock of the GOP, Trump comes in second in this category. They have brought it on themselves with constant rants opposing rational social and economic programs. They have demonized their opponents for years now, and the Proletariat is beginning to realize just what fabricators of the facts they are. Their promises have failed, their personal attacks on Democratic leaders have been shown to be despicable and mean spirited.

You can only get away with such for awhile, eventually it catches up to you. Now they are tied to two of the most unsavory candidates in their history. It is fun to watch the GOP self destruct, it has earned it.

Here are some facts for you. Hillary is way more honest than the Donald:
"Based on PolitiFact numbers, the percentage of statements by each presidential candidate rated to be “true” or “mostly true” were: John Kasich, 52 percent; Hillary Clinton, 50 percent; Bernie Sanders, 49 percent; Ted Cruz, 22 percent; and Donald Trump, 9 percent."

@jim emerson,
Reagan was replaced by bigots? Reagan is the ancestor to this bigoted bunch.

4-30-16@1:14 am

No. Absolutely not. You do not get to rewrite history on Reagan. He wasn't a "compassionate conservative". He was the President who started the all out war on the American middle class and the rights of women. He's just like Cruz and Trump--just with a "warmer" presentation. They are all enemies of their fellow Americans. Pure evil.
Don't give Reagan a pass. The ignorance and hate was enthusiastically cultivated by his henchmen.

Trump's goal is to destroy the Republican Party -- and the tradition of American conservatism -- from without; Cruz's is to destroy them from within. It's the Know-Nothing platform vs. the Tea Party platform. Nixon and Reagan, who negotiated trade agreements, arms limitation treaties with our enemies, and proposed economic stimulus packages, no longer fit inside the Republican Party tent. They are outcasts, victims of political climate-change in which conservative values have been fully replaced by bigotry, greed, self-centeredness, paranoia and xenophobia. Those are the values that unite both Cruz and Trump!
And we don't have to watch them in their new Fox News jobs.
Trump is a psychopath narcissist.   He will have a reality show based on his base.

@stu freeman,
I hope to heaven you're right, starting with his losing minus the "if."
As for any possible "I told you so," please, for the love of God, don't go there.

4-30-16@1:12 am

The Republican presidential candidates in this election cycle, current and former, are all, without exception, awful. It continues to be a race to the bottom, a contest that will be decided based on which of these blowhard egomaniacs panders most abjectly to the prejudiced, the paranoid, and the willfully ignorant that we now know abound in our country.

Even if he loses the primary or the general election, Trump will never go away. We will be hearing his obnoxious viewpoint and he will be encouraging violence and intolerance until he kicks the bucket. At least the others will traipse off into well deserved obscurity, so that is at least something in their favor. It isn't much, but it's something.
I think DYSPEPSIA can be used even for non-digestive upsets. Certainly a disagreeable person can be called DYSPEPTIC.
Agreed, pm, but the answer was DYSPEPSIA, not DUSPEPTIC.  So my confusion that is slowly abating is never having heard anyone say, "I have an UPSET."

Fair enough. But Merriam-Webster's Eleventh Collegiate defines DYSPEPSIA as

1) indigestion

2) ill humor : disgruntlement
Something seems missing in the clue for 61A: how is "upset" a complete clue for DYSPEPSIA?
Without question, Margalit Fox is the Offenbach of obit writers. Not perhaps the best; definitely so.
Kudos once again for Ms. Fox, perhaps the best obituary writer in the business today. The last paragraph -- But wait: There's more! -- is so perfectly crafted I began to weep.
I don't understand that omission either considering the notoriety that SNL skit still has some 35+ years later.
Margalit, you are something else.  But am I wrong to think the Bass-O-Matic would have been a nice tip of the hat to Mr. Kives?
What a shame David Letterman is not on his show to comment on Mr. Kives passing.

Where do you get the idea Canadian media were silent about Kives' death?

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketin...

http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/philip-kives-founder-of-k-tel-a...
The Globe and Mail ("Canada's National Newspaper") published a substantial obit a couple of days ago: http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketin...

Sad to hear of Mr. Kives' passing. K-tel products, especially the records, were such a huge part of my childhood in the 1970s and '80s. Many little kids and pre-teens loved K-tel records because they were cheaper than "real" albums, didn't seem to offend our parents, and gave access to a larger variety of music than we heard on the radio.

Interesting that the NYT published such a charming obituary, yet the Canadian media are silent about this legendary businessman's death. Probably many people didn't even know he was from Canada.
Without him there never would have been a "Bass-O-Matic."
Farewell and adieu as another slice of Americana or would that be Canadiana fades into yesterday.
Brilliant Meredith Willson homage!
And let's not forget the Super Bass-O-Matic '76 which could be a top seller in '16 with the current juice craze.

http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/video/irwin-mainway/n8641

When I remember Kives, I think of Dan Akroyd on SNL doing his "Bag O' Glass" routine and other toys that kill.
Nothing beats the Miracle Brush--we still use the one we bought in the 1970s. To this "Paganini of pitchmen" (great phrase by the way), RIP.

Only in the US would the Canadian marketer who brought us the "Veg-o-Matic" be eulogized on the front page of major newspaper.

Even though I’ve never seen a “Veg-o-Matic” in the flesh, so to speak, I'm still well trained by my childhood TV experience to know that it could also “slice and dice”. Among its many miracle features, I noted early on that it apparently could also rhyme.

What heaven or hell awaits the pitchman for the “Veg-o-Matic”? “Pitchman” makes me think of “pitch fork”, and a new gig in the after-life for the consummate salesman, pitching a “new and improved” version of the latter utensil to Lucifer, himself.
